title: Synthesis: From Meaning to Theological Claim
objective: Form clear theological propositions supported by text and context

required_passages.text: Now the righteousness of God has been manifested apart from the law, though the Law and the Prophets bear witness to it. All have sinned and fall short of the glory of God, and are justified freely by His grace through the redemption in Christ Jesus. God presented Christ as a propitiation by His blood to demonstrate His righteousness, being both just and the justifier of the one who has faith in Jesus.

segments.audio_script: This is lesson thirteen. Move from exegesis to theological synthesis.

Listen to the passage. Romans 3:21-26. Now the righteousness of God has been manifested apart from the law, though the Law and the Prophets bear witness to it. All have sinned and fall short of the glory of God, and are justified freely by His grace through the redemption in Christ Jesus. God presented Christ as a propitiation by His blood to demonstrate His righteousness, being both just and the justifier of the one who has faith in Jesus. Now identify the central theological claim and show how each sentence supports it.
Synthesis respects both the specific text and its canonical connections. Theological claim should be proportionate to textual evidence.
State your theological proposition, cite textual support, note genre influence, and specify limits of application.

What should a theological proposition include?
segments.correct_answer: A claim supported by textual evidence and contextual reasoning

study_notes: Avoid overclaiming; ensure claims are proportionate and tethered to the text's scope.
